prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Experience handling an MDL docket is clearly a factor that the Panel considers in evaluating whether a particular judge is a likely candidate for handling a particular docket.[1] This factor is of greatest weight for a judge who is both experienced in handling a prior MDL docket, but is not currently assigned one.[2] This is consistent with the Panel's tendency to favor “spreading” MDL dockets to districts that aren't currently handling any MDL dockets. See § 6:22.

The Panel may just as well select a transferee judge specifically because he or she is currently handling a related MDL docket.[3] The Panel's interest in assigning transferred litigation to a judge who has not presided over an MDL docket is more pronounced in recent years. The Panel has noted that experience handling in a complex docket involving the same type of case as now under consideration is germane to its decision.[4] Similarly, experience handling similar MDL litigation is something the Panel has noted as favoring a particular transferee judge.[5] Experience handling a related, but concluded MDL docket.[6] As important as experience with the transferee judge role is, the Panel in recent years has demonstrated a clear practice of spreading MDL assignments around. One upshot of this is the Panel's tendency to centralize dockets before a judge who is experienced but who is not currently handling any cases as a transferee judge.[7]

The Panel has also specifically noted that it was selecting a judge who had no prior experience as an MDL transferee judge.[8] A judge who has not “recently” received an MDL assignment may similarly be chosen by the Panel.[9] Without referencing MDL experience, the Panel occasionally may select a judge because of his or her experience handling complex litigation as a lawyer.[10] These cases illustrate the very pragmatic approach the panel takes to selection of a transferee judge. In a recent decision involving an exceptionally complex docket involving hundreds of cases representing claims of millions of potential claimants, foreign discovery issues, numerous different product models and brands, and involvement of multiple governmental entities, the Panel selected a judge who had handled nine earlier MDL dockets.[11]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

In re Viagara (Sildenafil Citrate) Products Liability Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Bair Hugger Forced Air Warming Devices Products Liability Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Medical Informatics Engineering, Inc., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Pacquiao-Mayweather Boxing Match Pay-Per-View Litigation, 122 F. Supp. 3d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Alibaba Group Holding Limited Securities Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Walgreens Herbal Supplements Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Disposable Contact Lens Antitrust Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1369 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Anthem, Inc. Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Amazon.com, Inc., Fulfillment Center Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Wage and Hour Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Collecto, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Nutramax Cosamin Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 988 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Monsanto Co. Genetically-Engineered Wheat Litigation, 978 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Bank of America Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) Contract Litigation, 746 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2010) (Panel notes “wealth of prior MDL experience” of transferee judge.); In re Puerto Rican Cabotage Antitrust Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Digitek Products Liability Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Texas Roadhouse Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA) Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Merscorp Inc., Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) Litigation, 473 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Intern. Air Transp. Surcharge Antitrust Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Celexa and Lexapro Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Vitamin C Antitrust Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (available judge with MDL experience); In re Viagra Products Liability Litigation, 414 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Commercial Money Center, Inc., Equipment Lease Litigation, 229 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002).

See, e.g., In re Apple iPhone 3G and 3GS MMS Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Pamidronate Products Liability Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Yasmin, Yaz (Drospirenone) Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1343 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Celexa and Lexapro Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re WellPoint, Inc., Out-of-Network UCR Rates Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Bayer Corp. Combination Aspirin Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 609 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Air Crash at Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on May 30, 2008, 598 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2009). See also In re Brican America LLC Equipment Lease Litigation, 731 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2010) (experienced transferee judge with only one other MDL docket).

See, e.g., In re: London Silver Fixing, Ltd., Antitrust Litigation, 52 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (notes as selection factor, but points out Panel is not suggest what degree of coordination ought to take place); In re Meridian Funds Group Securities & Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) Litigation, 645 F. Supp. 2d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Vonage Marketing and Sales Practices, 505 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (judge handling MDL docket against same common defendant).

See, e.g., In re Disposable Contact Lens Antitrust Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2015) (experience with cases involving anticompetitive conduct in same industry); In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005).
In re Payment Card Interchange Fee and Merchant Discount Antitrust Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005).

See, e.g., In re Flat Glass Antitrust Litigation (No. II), 559 F. Supp. 2d 1407 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (transfer to judge who had handled “In re Flat Glass Antitrust Litigation”); In re Payment Card Interchange Fee and Merchant Discount Antitrust Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005).

See, e.g., In re Yosemite Nat. Park Hantavirus Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Vehicle Carrier Services Antitrust Litigation, 978 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Prudential Ins. Co. of America SGLI/VGLI Contract Litigation, 763 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011); In re: Pamidronate Products Liability Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009); In re: Yasmin, Yaz (Drospirenone) Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1343 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009); In re: Bayer Corp. Combination Aspirin Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 609 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009); In Re Air Crash at Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on May 30, 2008, 598 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009) (Panel also notes judge has favorable overall caseload).

See, e.g., In re: Air Crash at Madrid, Spain, on August 20, 2008, 672 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
See In re: Toyota Motor Corp. Unintended Acceleration Marketing, Sales Practices, Products Liability Litigation, 704 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010).
See In re Volkswagen “Clean Diesel” Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 2015 WL 8543102 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015).
